2481  }
2482 
2483  virtual bool MatchAndExplain(Container container,
2484  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
2485 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_BEGIN_AND_END_
2486  using std::begin;
2487  using std::end;
2488  DistanceType distance = std::distance(begin(container), end(container));
2489 #else
2490  DistanceType distance = std::distance(container.begin(), container.end());
2491 #endif
2492  StringMatchResultListener distance_listener;
2493  const bool result =
2494  distance_matcher_.MatchAndExplain(distance, &distance_listener);
2495  *listener << "whose distance between begin() and end() " << distance
2496  << (result ? " matches" : " doesn't match");
2497  PrintIfNotEmpty(distance_listener.str(), listener->stream());
2498  return result;
2499  }
2500 
2501  private:
2502  const Matcher<DistanceType> distance_matcher_;
2503  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(Impl);
2504  };
2505 
2506  private:
2507  const DistanceMatcher distance_matcher_;
2508  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(BeginEndDistanceIsMatcher);
2509 };

2511 // Implements an equality matcher for any STL-style container whose elements
2512 // support ==. This matcher is like Eq(), but its failure explanations provide
2513 // more detailed information that is useful when the container is used as a set.
2514 // The failure message reports elements that are in one of the operands but not
2515 // the other. The failure messages do not report duplicate or out-of-order
2516 // elements in the containers (which don't properly matter to sets, but can
2517 // occur if the containers are vectors or lists, for example).
2518 //
2519 // Uses the container's const_iterator, value_type, operator ==,
2520 // begin(), and end().
2521 template <typename Container>
2522 class ContainerEqMatcher {
2523  public:
2524  typedef internal::StlContainerView<Container> View;
2525  typedef typename View::type StlContainer;
2526  typedef typename View::const_reference StlContainerReference;
2527 
2528  // We make a copy of expected in case the elements in it are modified
2529  // after this matcher is created.
2530  explicit ContainerEqMatcher(const Container& expected)
2531  : expected_(View::Copy(expected)) {
2532  // Makes sure the user doesn't instantiate this class template
2533  // with a const or reference type.
2534  (void)testing::StaticAssertTypeEq<Container,
2535  GTEST_REMOVE_REFERENCE_AND_CONST_(Container)>();
2536  }
2537 
2538  void DescribeTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
2539  *os << "equals ";
2540  UniversalPrint(expected_, os);
2541  }
2542  void DescribeNegationTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
2543  *os << "does not equal ";
2544  UniversalPrint(expected_, os);
2545  }
2546 
2547  template <typename LhsContainer>
2548  bool MatchAndExplain(const LhsContainer& lhs,
2549  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
2550  // GTEST_REMOVE_CONST_() is needed to work around an MSVC 8.0 bug
2551  // that causes LhsContainer to be a const type sometimes.
2552  typedef internal::StlContainerView<GTEST_REMOVE_CONST_(LhsContainer)>
2553  LhsView;
2554  typedef typename LhsView::type LhsStlContainer;
2555  StlContainerReference lhs_stl_container = LhsView::ConstReference(lhs);
2556  if (lhs_stl_container == expected_)
2557  return true;
2558 
2559  ::std::ostream* const os = listener->stream();
2560  if (os != NULL) {
2561  // Something is different. Check for extra values first.
2562  bool printed_header = false;
2563  for (typename LhsStlContainer::const_iterator it =
2564  lhs_stl_container.begin();
2565  it != lhs_stl_container.end(); ++it) {
2566  if (internal::ArrayAwareFind(expected_.begin(), expected_.end(), *it) ==
2567  expected_.end()) {
2568  if (printed_header) {
2569  *os << ", ";
2570  } else {
2571  *os << "which has these unexpected elements: ";
2572  printed_header = true;
2573  }
2574  UniversalPrint(*it, os);
2575  }
2576  }
2577 
2578  // Now check for missing values.
2579  bool printed_header2 = false;
2580  for (typename StlContainer::const_iterator it = expected_.begin();
2581  it != expected_.end(); ++it) {
2582  if (internal::ArrayAwareFind(
2583  lhs_stl_container.begin(), lhs_stl_container.end(), *it) ==
2584  lhs_stl_container.end()) {
2585  if (printed_header2) {
2586  *os << ", ";
2587  } else {
2588  *os << (printed_header ? ",\nand" : "which")
2589  << " doesn't have these expected elements: ";
2590  printed_header2 = true;
2591  }
2592  UniversalPrint(*it, os);
2593  }
2594  }
2595  }
2596 
2597  return false;
2598  }
2599 
2600  private:
2601  const StlContainer expected_;
2602 
2603  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(ContainerEqMatcher);
2604 };
2605 
2606 // A comparator functor that uses the < operator to compare two values.
2607 struct LessComparator {
2608  template <typename T, typename U>
2609  bool operator()(const T& lhs, const U& rhs) const { return lhs < rhs; }
2610 };

2612 // Implements WhenSortedBy(comparator, container_matcher).
2613 template <typename Comparator, typename ContainerMatcher>
2614 class WhenSortedByMatcher {
2615  public:
2616  WhenSortedByMatcher(const Comparator& comparator,
2617  const ContainerMatcher& matcher)
2618  : comparator_(comparator), matcher_(matcher) {}
2619 
2620  template <typename LhsContainer>
2621  operator Matcher<LhsContainer>() const {
2622  return MakeMatcher(new Impl<LhsContainer>(comparator_, matcher_));
2623  }
2624 
2625  template <typename LhsContainer>
2626  class Impl : public MatcherInterface<LhsContainer> {
2627  public:
2628  typedef internal::StlContainerView<
2629  GTEST_REMOVE_REFERENCE_AND_CONST_(LhsContainer)> LhsView;
2630  typedef typename LhsView::type LhsStlContainer;
2631  typedef typename LhsView::const_reference LhsStlContainerReference;
2632  // Transforms std::pair<const Key, Value> into std::pair<Key, Value>
2633  // so that we can match associative containers.
2634  typedef typename RemoveConstFromKey<
2635  typename LhsStlContainer::value_type>::type LhsValue;
2636 
2637  Impl(const Comparator& comparator, const ContainerMatcher& matcher)
2638  : comparator_(comparator), matcher_(matcher) {}
2639 
2640  virtual void DescribeTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
2641  *os << "(when sorted) ";
2642  matcher_.DescribeTo(os);
2643  }
2644 
2645  virtual void DescribeNegationTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
2646  *os << "(when sorted) ";
2647  matcher_.DescribeNegationTo(os);
2648  }
2649 
2650  virtual bool MatchAndExplain(LhsContainer lhs,
2651  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
2652  LhsStlContainerReference lhs_stl_container = LhsView::ConstReference(lhs);
2653  ::std::vector<LhsValue> sorted_container(lhs_stl_container.begin(),
2654  lhs_stl_container.end());
2655  ::std::sort(
2656  sorted_container.begin(), sorted_container.end(), comparator_);
2657 
2658  if (!listener->IsInterested()) {
2659  // If the listener is not interested, we do not need to
2660  // construct the inner explanation.
2661  return matcher_.Matches(sorted_container);
2662  }
2663 
2664  *listener << "which is ";
2665  UniversalPrint(sorted_container, listener->stream());
2666  *listener << " when sorted";
2667 
2668  StringMatchResultListener inner_listener;
2669  const bool match = matcher_.MatchAndExplain(sorted_container,
2670  &inner_listener);
2671  PrintIfNotEmpty(inner_listener.str(), listener->stream());
2672  return match;
2673  }
2674 
2675  private:
2676  const Comparator comparator_;
2677  const Matcher<const ::std::vector<LhsValue>&> matcher_;
2678 
2679  GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(Impl);
2680  };
2681 
2682  private:
2683  const Comparator comparator_;
2684  const ContainerMatcher matcher_;
2685 
2686  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(WhenSortedByMatcher);
2687 };

2689 // Implements Pointwise(tuple_matcher, rhs_container). tuple_matcher
2690 // must be able to be safely cast to Matcher<tuple<const T1&, const
2691 // T2&> >, where T1 and T2 are the types of elements in the LHS
2692 // container and the RHS container respectively.
2693 template <typename TupleMatcher, typename RhsContainer>
2694 class PointwiseMatcher {
2695  public:
2696  typedef internal::StlContainerView<RhsContainer> RhsView;
2697  typedef typename RhsView::type RhsStlContainer;
2698  typedef typename RhsStlContainer::value_type RhsValue;
2699 
2700  // Like ContainerEq, we make a copy of rhs in case the elements in
2701  // it are modified after this matcher is created.
2702  PointwiseMatcher(const TupleMatcher& tuple_matcher, const RhsContainer& rhs)
2703  : tuple_matcher_(tuple_matcher), rhs_(RhsView::Copy(rhs)) {
2704  // Makes sure the user doesn't instantiate this class template
2705  // with a const or reference type.
2706  (void)testing::StaticAssertTypeEq<RhsContainer,
2707  GTEST_REMOVE_REFERENCE_AND_CONST_(RhsContainer)>();
2708  }
2709 
2710  template <typename LhsContainer>
2711  operator Matcher<LhsContainer>() const {
2712  return MakeMatcher(new Impl<LhsContainer>(tuple_matcher_, rhs_));
2713  }
2714 
2715  template <typename LhsContainer>
2716  class Impl : public MatcherInterface<LhsContainer> {
2717  public:
2718  typedef internal::StlContainerView<
2719  GTEST_REMOVE_REFERENCE_AND_CONST_(LhsContainer)> LhsView;
2720  typedef typename LhsView::type LhsStlContainer;
2721  typedef typename LhsView::const_reference LhsStlContainerReference;
2722  typedef typename LhsStlContainer::value_type LhsValue;
2723  // We pass the LHS value and the RHS value to the inner matcher by
2724  // reference, as they may be expensive to copy. We must use tuple
2725  // instead of pair here, as a pair cannot hold references (C++ 98,
2726  // 20.2.2 [lib.pairs]).
2727  typedef ::testing::tuple<const LhsValue&, const RhsValue&> InnerMatcherArg;
2728 
2729  Impl(const TupleMatcher& tuple_matcher, const RhsStlContainer& rhs)
2730  // mono_tuple_matcher_ holds a monomorphic version of the tuple matcher.
2731  : mono_tuple_matcher_(SafeMatcherCast<InnerMatcherArg>(tuple_matcher)),
2732  rhs_(rhs) {}
2733 
2734  virtual void DescribeTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
2735  *os << "contains " << rhs_.size()
2736  << " values, where each value and its corresponding value in ";
2737  UniversalPrinter<RhsStlContainer>::Print(rhs_, os);
2738  *os << " ";
2739  mono_tuple_matcher_.DescribeTo(os);
2740  }
2741  virtual void DescribeNegationTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
2742  *os << "doesn't contain exactly " << rhs_.size()
2743  << " values, or contains a value x at some index i"
2744  << " where x and the i-th value of ";
2745  UniversalPrint(rhs_, os);
2746  *os << " ";
2747  mono_tuple_matcher_.DescribeNegationTo(os);
2748  }
2749 
2750  virtual bool MatchAndExplain(LhsContainer lhs,
2751  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
2752  LhsStlContainerReference lhs_stl_container = LhsView::ConstReference(lhs);
2753  const size_t actual_size = lhs_stl_container.size();
2754  if (actual_size != rhs_.size()) {
2755  *listener << "which contains " << actual_size << " values";
2756  return false;
2757  }
2758 
2759  typename LhsStlContainer::const_iterator left = lhs_stl_container.begin();
2760  typename RhsStlContainer::const_iterator right = rhs_.begin();
2761  for (size_t i = 0; i != actual_size; ++i, ++left, ++right) {
2762  const InnerMatcherArg value_pair(*left, *right);
2763 
2764  if (listener->IsInterested()) {
2765  StringMatchResultListener inner_listener;
2766  if (!mono_tuple_matcher_.MatchAndExplain(
2767  value_pair, &inner_listener)) {
2768  *listener << "where the value pair (";
2769  UniversalPrint(*left, listener->stream());
2770  *listener << ", ";
2771  UniversalPrint(*right, listener->stream());
2772  *listener << ") at index #" << i << " don't match";
2773  PrintIfNotEmpty(inner_listener.str(), listener->stream());
2774  return false;
2775  }
2776  } else {
2777  if (!mono_tuple_matcher_.Matches(value_pair))
2778  return false;
2779  }
2780  }
2781 
2782  return true;
2783  }
2784 
2785  private:
2786  const Matcher<InnerMatcherArg> mono_tuple_matcher_;
2787  const RhsStlContainer rhs_;
2788 
2789  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(Impl);
2790  };
2791 
2792  private:
2793  const TupleMatcher tuple_matcher_;
2794  const RhsStlContainer rhs_;
2795 
2796  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(PointwiseMatcher);
2797 };
2798 
2799 // Holds the logic common to ContainsMatcherImpl and EachMatcherImpl.
2800 template <typename Container>
2801 class QuantifierMatcherImpl : public MatcherInterface<Container> {
2802  public:
2803  typedef GTEST_REMOVE_REFERENCE_AND_CONST_(Container) RawContainer;
2804  typedef StlContainerView<RawContainer> View;
2805  typedef typename View::type StlContainer;
2806  typedef typename View::const_reference StlContainerReference;
2807  typedef typename StlContainer::value_type Element;
2808 
2809  template <typename InnerMatcher>
2810  explicit QuantifierMatcherImpl(InnerMatcher inner_matcher)
2811  : inner_matcher_(
2812  testing::SafeMatcherCast<const Element&>(inner_matcher)) {}
2813 
2814  // Checks whether:
2815  // * All elements in the container match, if all_elements_should_match.
2816  // * Any element in the container matches, if !all_elements_should_match.
2817  bool MatchAndExplainImpl(bool all_elements_should_match,
2818  Container container,
2819  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
2820  StlContainerReference stl_container = View::ConstReference(container);
2821  size_t i = 0;
2822  for (typename StlContainer::const_iterator it = stl_container.begin();
2823  it != stl_container.end(); ++it, ++i) {
2824  StringMatchResultListener inner_listener;
2825  const bool matches = inner_matcher_.MatchAndExplain(*it, &inner_listener);
2826 
2827  if (matches != all_elements_should_match) {
2828  *listener << "whose element #" << i
2829  << (matches ? " matches" : " doesn't match");
2830  PrintIfNotEmpty(inner_listener.str(), listener->stream());
2831  return !all_elements_should_match;
2832  }
2833  }
2834  return all_elements_should_match;
2835  }
2836 
2837  protected:
2838  const Matcher<const Element&> inner_matcher_;
2839 
2840  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(QuantifierMatcherImpl);
2841 };
2842

2847  public:
2848  template <typename InnerMatcher>
2849  explicit ContainsMatcherImpl(InnerMatcher inner_matcher)
2850  : QuantifierMatcherImpl<Container>(inner_matcher) {}

2853  virtual void DescribeTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
2854  *os << "contains at least one element that ";
2855  this->inner_matcher_.DescribeTo(os);
2856  }
2857 
2858  virtual void DescribeNegationTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
2859  *os << "doesn't contain any element that ";
2860  this->inner_matcher_.DescribeTo(os);
2861  }
2862 
2863  virtual bool MatchAndExplain(Container container,
2864  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
2865  return this->MatchAndExplainImpl(false, container, listener);
2866  }

2868  private:

2935 // Implements Key(inner_matcher) for the given argument pair type.
2936 // Key(inner_matcher) matches an std::pair whose 'first' field matches
2937 // inner_matcher. For example, Contains(Key(Ge(5))) can be used to match an
2938 // std::map that contains at least one element whose key is >= 5.
2939 template <typename PairType>
2940 class KeyMatcherImpl : public MatcherInterface<PairType> {
2941  public:
2942  typedef GTEST_REMOVE_REFERENCE_AND_CONST_(PairType) RawPairType;
2943  typedef typename RawPairType::first_type KeyType;
2944

2947  : inner_matcher_(
2948  testing::SafeMatcherCast<const KeyType&>(inner_matcher)) {
2949  }
2950 
2951  // Returns true iff 'key_value.first' (the key) matches the inner matcher.
2952  virtual bool MatchAndExplain(PairType key_value,
2953  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
2954  StringMatchResultListener inner_listener;
2955  const bool match = inner_matcher_.MatchAndExplain(key_value.first,
2956  &inner_listener);
2957  const std::string explanation = inner_listener.str();
2958  if (explanation != "") {
2959  *listener << "whose first field is a value " << explanation;
2960  }
2961  return match;
2962  }
2963 
2964  // Describes what this matcher does.
2965  virtual void DescribeTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
2966  *os << "has a key that ";
2967  inner_matcher_.DescribeTo(os);
2968  }
2969 
2970  // Describes what the negation of this matcher does.
2971  virtual void DescribeNegationTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
2972  *os << "doesn't have a key that ";
2973  inner_matcher_.DescribeTo(os);
2974  }
2975 
2976  private:
2977  const Matcher<const KeyType&> inner_matcher_;
2978 
2979  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(KeyMatcherImpl);
2980 };

2999 // Implements Pair(first_matcher, second_matcher) for the given argument pair
3000 // type with its two matchers. See Pair() function below.
3001 template <typename PairType>
3002 class PairMatcherImpl : public MatcherInterface<PairType> {
3003  public:
3004  typedef GTEST_REMOVE_REFERENCE_AND_CONST_(PairType) RawPairType;
3005  typedef typename RawPairType::first_type FirstType;
3006  typedef typename RawPairType::second_type SecondType;
3007 
3008  template <typename FirstMatcher, typename SecondMatcher>
3009  PairMatcherImpl(FirstMatcher first_matcher, SecondMatcher second_matcher)
3010  : first_matcher_(
3011  testing::SafeMatcherCast<const FirstType&>(first_matcher)),
3012  second_matcher_(
3013  testing::SafeMatcherCast<const SecondType&>(second_matcher)) {
3014  }
3015 
3016  // Describes what this matcher does.
3017  virtual void DescribeTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
3018  *os << "has a first field that ";
3019  first_matcher_.DescribeTo(os);
3020  *os << ", and has a second field that ";
3021  second_matcher_.DescribeTo(os);
3022  }
3023 
3024  // Describes what the negation of this matcher does.
3025  virtual void DescribeNegationTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
3026  *os << "has a first field that ";
3027  first_matcher_.DescribeNegationTo(os);
3028  *os << ", or has a second field that ";
3029  second_matcher_.DescribeNegationTo(os);
3030  }
3031 
3032  // Returns true iff 'a_pair.first' matches first_matcher and 'a_pair.second'
3033  // matches second_matcher.
3034  virtual bool MatchAndExplain(PairType a_pair,
3035  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
3036  if (!listener->IsInterested()) {
3037  // If the listener is not interested, we don't need to construct the
3038  // explanation.
3039  return first_matcher_.Matches(a_pair.first) &&
3040  second_matcher_.Matches(a_pair.second);
3041  }
3042  StringMatchResultListener first_inner_listener;
3043  if (!first_matcher_.MatchAndExplain(a_pair.first,
3044  &first_inner_listener)) {
3045  *listener << "whose first field does not match";
3046  PrintIfNotEmpty(first_inner_listener.str(), listener->stream());
3047  return false;
3048  }
3049  StringMatchResultListener second_inner_listener;
3050  if (!second_matcher_.MatchAndExplain(a_pair.second,
3051  &second_inner_listener)) {
3052  *listener << "whose second field does not match";
3053  PrintIfNotEmpty(second_inner_listener.str(), listener->stream());
3054  return false;
3055  }
3056  ExplainSuccess(first_inner_listener.str(), second_inner_listener.str(),
3057  listener);
3058  return true;
3059  }
3060 
3061  private:
3062  void ExplainSuccess(const std::string& first_explanation,
3063  const std::string& second_explanation,
3064  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
3065  *listener << "whose both fields match";
3066  if (first_explanation != "") {
3067  *listener << ", where the first field is a value " << first_explanation;
3068  }
3069  if (second_explanation != "") {
3070  *listener << ", ";
3071  if (first_explanation != "") {
3072  *listener << "and ";
3073  } else {
3074  *listener << "where ";
3075  }
3076  *listener << "the second field is a value " << second_explanation;
3077  }
3078  }
3079 
3080  const Matcher<const FirstType&> first_matcher_;
3081  const Matcher<const SecondType&> second_matcher_;
3082 
3083  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(PairMatcherImpl);
3084 };
3085 
3086 // Implements polymorphic Pair(first_matcher, second_matcher).
3087 template <typename FirstMatcher, typename SecondMatcher>
3088 class PairMatcher {
3089  public:
3090  PairMatcher(FirstMatcher first_matcher, SecondMatcher second_matcher)
3091  : first_matcher_(first_matcher), second_matcher_(second_matcher) {}
3092 
3093  template <typename PairType>
3094  operator Matcher<PairType> () const {
3095  return MakeMatcher(
3096  new PairMatcherImpl<PairType>(
3097  first_matcher_, second_matcher_));
3098  }
3099 
3100  private:
3101  const FirstMatcher first_matcher_;
3102  const SecondMatcher second_matcher_;
3103 
3104  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(PairMatcher);
3105 };

3107 // Implements ElementsAre() and ElementsAreArray().
3108 template <typename Container>
3109 class ElementsAreMatcherImpl : public MatcherInterface<Container> {
3110  public:
3111  typedef GTEST_REMOVE_REFERENCE_AND_CONST_(Container) RawContainer;
3112  typedef internal::StlContainerView<RawContainer> View;
3113  typedef typename View::type StlContainer;
3114  typedef typename View::const_reference StlContainerReference;
3115  typedef typename StlContainer::value_type Element;
3116 
3117  // Constructs the matcher from a sequence of element values or
3118  // element matchers.
3119  template <typename InputIter>
3120  ElementsAreMatcherImpl(InputIter first, InputIter last) {
3121  while (first != last) {
3122  matchers_.push_back(MatcherCast<const Element&>(*first++));
3123  }
3124  }
3125 
3126  // Describes what this matcher does.
3127  virtual void DescribeTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
3128  if (count() == 0) {
3129  *os << "is empty";
3130  } else if (count() == 1) {
3131  *os << "has 1 element that ";
3132  matchers_[0].DescribeTo(os);
3133  } else {
3134  *os << "has " << Elements(count()) << " where\n";
3135  for (size_t i = 0; i != count(); ++i) {
3136  *os << "element #" << i << " ";
3137  matchers_[i].DescribeTo(os);
3138  if (i + 1 < count()) {
3139  *os << ",\n";
3140  }
3141  }
3142  }
3143  }
3144 
3145  // Describes what the negation of this matcher does.
3146  virtual void DescribeNegationTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
3147  if (count() == 0) {
3148  *os << "isn't empty";
3149  return;
3150  }
3151 
3152  *os << "doesn't have " << Elements(count()) << ", or\n";
3153  for (size_t i = 0; i != count(); ++i) {
3154  *os << "element #" << i << " ";
3155  matchers_[i].DescribeNegationTo(os);
3156  if (i + 1 < count()) {
3157  *os << ", or\n";
3158  }
3159  }
3160  }
3161 
3162  virtual bool MatchAndExplain(Container container,
3163  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
3164  // To work with stream-like "containers", we must only walk
3165  // through the elements in one pass.
3166 
3167  const bool listener_interested = listener->IsInterested();
3168 
3169  // explanations[i] is the explanation of the element at index i.
3170  ::std::vector<std::string> explanations(count());
3171  StlContainerReference stl_container = View::ConstReference(container);
3172  typename StlContainer::const_iterator it = stl_container.begin();
3173  size_t exam_pos = 0;
3174  bool mismatch_found = false; // Have we found a mismatched element yet?
3175 
3176  // Go through the elements and matchers in pairs, until we reach
3177  // the end of either the elements or the matchers, or until we find a
3178  // mismatch.
3179  for (; it != stl_container.end() && exam_pos != count(); ++it, ++exam_pos) {
3180  bool match; // Does the current element match the current matcher?
3181  if (listener_interested) {
3182  StringMatchResultListener s;
3183  match = matchers_[exam_pos].MatchAndExplain(*it, &s);
3184  explanations[exam_pos] = s.str();
3185  } else {
3186  match = matchers_[exam_pos].Matches(*it);
3187  }
3188 
3189  if (!match) {
3190  mismatch_found = true;
3191  break;
3192  }
3193  }
3194  // If mismatch_found is true, 'exam_pos' is the index of the mismatch.
3195 
3196  // Find how many elements the actual container has. We avoid
3197  // calling size() s.t. this code works for stream-like "containers"
3198  // that don't define size().
3199  size_t actual_count = exam_pos;
3200  for (; it != stl_container.end(); ++it) {
3201  ++actual_count;
3202  }
3203 
3204  if (actual_count != count()) {
3205  // The element count doesn't match. If the container is empty,
3206  // there's no need to explain anything as Google Mock already
3207  // prints the empty container. Otherwise we just need to show
3208  // how many elements there actually are.
3209  if (listener_interested && (actual_count != 0)) {
3210  *listener << "which has " << Elements(actual_count);
3211  }
3212  return false;
3213  }
3214 
3215  if (mismatch_found) {
3216  // The element count matches, but the exam_pos-th element doesn't match.
3217  if (listener_interested) {
3218  *listener << "whose element #" << exam_pos << " doesn't match";
3219  PrintIfNotEmpty(explanations[exam_pos], listener->stream());
3220  }
3221  return false;
3222  }
3223 
3224  // Every element matches its expectation. We need to explain why
3225  // (the obvious ones can be skipped).
3226  if (listener_interested) {
3227  bool reason_printed = false;
3228  for (size_t i = 0; i != count(); ++i) {
3229  const std::string& s = explanations[i];
3230  if (!s.empty()) {
3231  if (reason_printed) {
3232  *listener << ",\nand ";
3233  }
3234  *listener << "whose element #" << i << " matches, " << s;
3235  reason_printed = true;
3236  }
3237  }
3238  }
3239  return true;
3240  }
3241 
3242  private:
3243  static Message Elements(size_t count) {
3244  return Message() << count << (count == 1 ? " element" : " elements");
3245  }
3246 
3247  size_t count() const { return matchers_.size(); }
3248 
3249  ::std::vector<Matcher<const Element&> > matchers_;
3250 
3251  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(ElementsAreMatcherImpl);
3252 };
3253 
3254 // Connectivity matrix of (elements X matchers), in element-major order.
3255 // Initially, there are no edges.
3256 // Use NextGraph() to iterate over all possible edge configurations.
3257 // Use Randomize() to generate a random edge configuration.
3258 class GTEST_API_ MatchMatrix {
3259  public:
3260  MatchMatrix(size_t num_elements, size_t num_matchers)
3261  : num_elements_(num_elements),
3262  num_matchers_(num_matchers),
3263  matched_(num_elements_* num_matchers_, 0) {
3264  }
3265 
3266  size_t LhsSize() const { return num_elements_; }
3267  size_t RhsSize() const { return num_matchers_; }
3268  bool HasEdge(size_t ilhs, size_t irhs) const {
3269  return matched_[SpaceIndex(ilhs, irhs)] == 1;
3270  }
3271  void SetEdge(size_t ilhs, size_t irhs, bool b) {
3272  matched_[SpaceIndex(ilhs, irhs)] = b ? 1 : 0;
3273  }
3274 
3275  // Treating the connectivity matrix as a (LhsSize()*RhsSize())-bit number,
3276  // adds 1 to that number; returns false if incrementing the graph left it
3277  // empty.
3278  bool NextGraph();
3279 
3280  void Randomize();
3281 
3282  std::string DebugString() const;
3283 
3284  private:
3285  size_t SpaceIndex(size_t ilhs, size_t irhs) const {
3286  return ilhs * num_matchers_ + irhs;
3287  }
3288 
3289  size_t num_elements_;
3290  size_t num_matchers_;
3291 
3292  // Each element is a char interpreted as bool. They are stored as a
3293  // flattened array in lhs-major order, use 'SpaceIndex()' to translate
3294  // a (ilhs, irhs) matrix coordinate into an offset.
3295  ::std::vector<char> matched_;
3296 };

3299 typedef ::std::vector<ElementMatcherPair> ElementMatcherPairs;

3303 GTEST_API_ ElementMatcherPairs
3304 FindMaxBipartiteMatching(const MatchMatrix& g);

3358 // Implements UnorderedElementsAre, UnorderedElementsAreArray, IsSubsetOf, and
3359 // IsSupersetOf.
3360 template <typename Container>
3361 class UnorderedElementsAreMatcherImpl
3362  : public MatcherInterface<Container>,
3363  public UnorderedElementsAreMatcherImplBase {
3364  public:
3365  typedef GTEST_REMOVE_REFERENCE_AND_CONST_(Container) RawContainer;
3366  typedef internal::StlContainerView<RawContainer> View;
3367  typedef typename View::type StlContainer;
3368  typedef typename View::const_reference StlContainerReference;
3369  typedef typename StlContainer::const_iterator StlContainerConstIterator;
3370  typedef typename StlContainer::value_type Element;
3371 
3372  template <typename InputIter>
3373  UnorderedElementsAreMatcherImpl(UnorderedMatcherRequire::Flags matcher_flags,
3374  InputIter first, InputIter last)
3375  : UnorderedElementsAreMatcherImplBase(matcher_flags) {
3376  for (; first != last; ++first) {
3377  matchers_.push_back(MatcherCast<const Element&>(*first));
3378  matcher_describers().push_back(matchers_.back().GetDescriber());
3379  }
3380  }
3381 
3382  // Describes what this matcher does.
3383  virtual void DescribeTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
3384  return UnorderedElementsAreMatcherImplBase::DescribeToImpl(os);
3385  }
3386 
3387  // Describes what the negation of this matcher does.
3388  virtual void DescribeNegationTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
3389  return UnorderedElementsAreMatcherImplBase::DescribeNegationToImpl(os);
3390  }
3391 
3392  virtual bool MatchAndExplain(Container container,
3393  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
3394  StlContainerReference stl_container = View::ConstReference(container);
3395  ::std::vector<std::string> element_printouts;
3396  MatchMatrix matrix =
3397  AnalyzeElements(stl_container.begin(), stl_container.end(),
3398  &element_printouts, listener);
3399 
3400  if (matrix.LhsSize() == 0 && matrix.RhsSize() == 0) {
3401  return true;
3402  }
3403 
3404  if (match_flags() == UnorderedMatcherRequire::ExactMatch) {
3405  if (matrix.LhsSize() != matrix.RhsSize()) {
3406  // The element count doesn't match. If the container is empty,
3407  // there's no need to explain anything as Google Mock already
3408  // prints the empty container. Otherwise we just need to show
3409  // how many elements there actually are.
3410  if (matrix.LhsSize() != 0 && listener->IsInterested()) {
3411  *listener << "which has " << Elements(matrix.LhsSize());
3412  }
3413  return false;
3414  }
3415  }
3416 
3417  return VerifyMatchMatrix(element_printouts, matrix, listener) &&
3418  FindPairing(matrix, listener);
3419  }
3420 
3421  private:
3422  template <typename ElementIter>
3423  MatchMatrix AnalyzeElements(ElementIter elem_first, ElementIter elem_last,
3424  ::std::vector<std::string>* element_printouts,
3425  MatchResultListener* listener) const {
3426  element_printouts->clear();
3427  ::std::vector<char> did_match;
3428  size_t num_elements = 0;
3429  for (; elem_first != elem_last; ++num_elements, ++elem_first) {
3430  if (listener->IsInterested()) {
3431  element_printouts->push_back(PrintToString(*elem_first));
3432  }
3433  for (size_t irhs = 0; irhs != matchers_.size(); ++irhs) {
3434  did_match.push_back(Matches(matchers_[irhs])(*elem_first));
3435  }
3436  }
3437 
3438  MatchMatrix matrix(num_elements, matchers_.size());
3439  ::std::vector<char>::const_iterator did_match_iter = did_match.begin();
3440  for (size_t ilhs = 0; ilhs != num_elements; ++ilhs) {
3441  for (size_t irhs = 0; irhs != matchers_.size(); ++irhs) {
3442  matrix.SetEdge(ilhs, irhs, *did_match_iter++ != 0);
3443  }
3444  }
3445  return matrix;
3446  }
3447 
3448  ::std::vector<Matcher<const Element&> > matchers_;
3449 
3450  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(UnorderedElementsAreMatcherImpl);
3451 };

3555 // Given a 2-tuple matcher tm of type Tuple2Matcher and a value second
3556 // of type Second, BoundSecondMatcher<Tuple2Matcher, Second>(tm,
3557 // second) is a polymorphic matcher that matches a value x iff tm
3558 // matches tuple (x, second). Useful for implementing
3559 // UnorderedPointwise() in terms of UnorderedElementsAreArray().
3560 //
3561 // BoundSecondMatcher is copyable and assignable, as we need to put
3562 // instances of this class in a vector when implementing
3563 // UnorderedPointwise().
3564 template <typename Tuple2Matcher, typename Second>
3565 class BoundSecondMatcher {
3566  public:
3567  BoundSecondMatcher(const Tuple2Matcher& tm, const Second& second)
3568  : tuple2_matcher_(tm), second_value_(second) {}
3569 
3570  template <typename T>
3571  operator Matcher<T>() const {
3572  return MakeMatcher(new Impl<T>(tuple2_matcher_, second_value_));
3573  }
3574 
3575  // We have to define this for UnorderedPointwise() to compile in
3576  // C++98 mode, as it puts BoundSecondMatcher instances in a vector,
3577  // which requires the elements to be assignable in C++98. The
3578  // compiler cannot generate the operator= for us, as Tuple2Matcher
3579  // and Second may not be assignable.
3580  //
3581  // However, this should never be called, so the implementation just
3582  // need to assert.
3583  void operator=(const BoundSecondMatcher& /*rhs*/) {
3584  GTEST_LOG_(FATAL) << "BoundSecondMatcher should never be assigned.";
3585  }
3586 
3587  private:
3588  template <typename T>
3589  class Impl : public MatcherInterface<T> {
3590  public:
3591  typedef ::testing::tuple<T, Second> ArgTuple;
3592 
3593  Impl(const Tuple2Matcher& tm, const Second& second)
3594  : mono_tuple2_matcher_(SafeMatcherCast<const ArgTuple&>(tm)),
3595  second_value_(second) {}
3596 
3597  virtual void DescribeTo(::std::ostream* os) const {
3598  *os << "and ";
3599  UniversalPrint(second_value_, os);
3600  *os << " ";
3601  mono_tuple2_matcher_.DescribeTo(os);
3602  }
3603 
3604  virtual bool MatchAndExplain(T x, MatchResultListener* listener) const {
3605  return mono_tuple2_matcher_.MatchAndExplain(ArgTuple(x, second_value_),
3606  listener);
3607  }
3608 
3609  private:
3610  const Matcher<const ArgTuple&> mono_tuple2_matcher_;
3611  const Second second_value_;
3612 
3613  GTEST_DISALLOW_ASSIGN_(Impl);
3614  };
3615 
3616  const Tuple2Matcher tuple2_matcher_;
3617  const Second second_value_;
3618 };

3646 // Implements a matcher that checks the value of a variant<> type variable.
3647 template <typename T>
3648 class VariantMatcher {
3649  public:
3650  explicit VariantMatcher(::testing::Matcher<const T&> matcher)
3651  : matcher_(internal::move(matcher)) {}
3652 
3653  template <typename Variant>
3654  bool MatchAndExplain(const Variant& value,
3655  ::testing::MatchResultListener* listener) const {
3656  if (!listener->IsInterested()) {
3657  return holds_alternative<T>(value) && matcher_.Matches(get<T>(value));
3658  }
3659 
3660  if (!holds_alternative<T>(value)) {
3661  *listener << "whose value is not of type '" << GetTypeName() << "'";
3662  return false;
3663  }
3664 
3665  const T& elem = get<T>(value);
3666  StringMatchResultListener elem_listener;
3667  const bool match = matcher_.MatchAndExplain(elem, &elem_listener);
3668  *listener << "whose value " << PrintToString(elem)
3669  << (match ? " matches" : " doesn't match");
3670  PrintIfNotEmpty(elem_listener.str(), listener->stream());
3671  return match;
3672  }

3675  *os << "is a variant<> with value of type '" << GetTypeName()
3676  << "' and the value ";
3677  matcher_.DescribeTo(os);
3678  }
3679 
3680  void DescribeNegationTo(std::ostream* os) const {
3681  *os << "is a variant<> with value of type other than '" << GetTypeName()
3682  << "' or the value ";
3683  matcher_.DescribeNegationTo(os);
3684  }
3685 
3686  private:
3687  static string GetTypeName() {
3688 #if GTEST_HAS_RTTI
3689  return internal::GetTypeName<T>();
3690 #endif
3691  return "the element type";
3692  }
3693 
3694  const ::testing::Matcher<const T&> matcher_;
3695 };

3701 // ElementsAreArray(iterator_first, iterator_last)
3702 // ElementsAreArray(pointer, count)
3703 // ElementsAreArray(array)
3704 // ElementsAreArray(container)
3705 // ElementsAreArray({ e1, e2, ..., en })
3706 //
3707 // The ElementsAreArray() functions are like ElementsAre(...), except
3708 // that they are given a homogeneous sequence rather than taking each
3709 // element as a function argument. The sequence can be specified as an
3710 // array, a pointer and count, a vector, an initializer list, or an
3711 // STL iterator range. In each of these cases, the underlying sequence
3712 // can be either a sequence of values or a sequence of matchers.
3713 //
3714 // All forms of ElementsAreArray() make a copy of the input matcher sequence.
3715 
3716 template <typename Iter>

3750 // UnorderedElementsAreArray(iterator_first, iterator_last)
3751 // UnorderedElementsAreArray(pointer, count)
3752 // UnorderedElementsAreArray(array)
3753 // UnorderedElementsAreArray(container)
3754 // UnorderedElementsAreArray({ e1, e2, ..., en })
3755 //
3756 // UnorderedElementsAreArray() verifies that a bijective mapping onto a
3757 // collection of matchers exists.
3758 //
3759 // The matchers can be specified as an array, a pointer and count, a container,
3760 // an initializer list, or an STL iterator range. In each of these cases, the
3761 // underlying matchers can be either values or matchers.
3762 
3763 template <typename Iter>
3764 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<
3765  typename ::std::iterator_traits<Iter>::value_type>
3766 UnorderedElementsAreArray(Iter first, Iter last) {
3767  typedef typename ::std::iterator_traits<Iter>::value_type T;
3768  return internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T>(
3769  internal::UnorderedMatcherRequire::ExactMatch, first, last);
3770 }
3771 
3772 template <typename T>
3773 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T>
3774 UnorderedElementsAreArray(const T* pointer, size_t count) {
3775  return UnorderedElementsAreArray(pointer, pointer + count);
3776 }
3777 
3778 template <typename T, size_t N>
3779 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T>
3780 UnorderedElementsAreArray(const T (&array)[N]) {
3781  return UnorderedElementsAreArray(array, N);
3782 }
3783 
3784 template <typename Container>
3785 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<
3786  typename Container::value_type>
3787 UnorderedElementsAreArray(const Container& container) {
3788  return UnorderedElementsAreArray(container.begin(), container.end());
3789 }
3790 
3791 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_INITIALIZER_LIST_
3792 template <typename T>
3793 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T>
3794 UnorderedElementsAreArray(::std::initializer_list<T> xs) {
3795  return UnorderedElementsAreArray(xs.begin(), xs.end());

3799 // _ is a matcher that matches anything of any type.
3800 //
3801 // This definition is fine as:
3802 //
3803 // 1. The C++ standard permits using the name _ in a namespace that
3804 // is not the global namespace or ::std.
3805 // 2. The AnythingMatcher class has no data member or constructor,
3806 // so it's OK to create global variables of this type.
3807 // 3. c-style has approved of using _ in this case.
3808 const internal::AnythingMatcher _ = {};
3809 // Creates a matcher that matches any value of the given type T.
3810 template <typename T>
3811 inline Matcher<T> A() {
3812  return Matcher<T>(new internal::AnyMatcherImpl<T>());
3813 }

3816 template <typename T>
3817 inline Matcher<T> An() { return A<T>(); }

3819 // Creates a polymorphic matcher that matches anything equal to x.
3820 // Note: if the parameter of Eq() were declared as const T&, Eq("foo")
3821 // wouldn't compile.
3822 template <typename T>
3823 inline internal::EqMatcher<T> Eq(T x) { return internal::EqMatcher<T>(x); }
3824 
3825 // Constructs a Matcher<T> from a 'value' of type T. The constructed
3826 // matcher matches any value that's equal to 'value'.
3827 template <typename T>
3828 Matcher<T>::Matcher(T value) { *this = Eq(value); }
3829 
3830 // Creates a monomorphic matcher that matches anything with type Lhs
3831 // and equal to rhs. A user may need to use this instead of Eq(...)
3832 // in order to resolve an overloading ambiguity.
3833 //
3834 // TypedEq<T>(x) is just a convenient short-hand for Matcher<T>(Eq(x))
3835 // or Matcher<T>(x), but more readable than the latter.
3836 //
3837 // We could define similar monomorphic matchers for other comparison
3838 // operations (e.g. TypedLt, TypedGe, and etc), but decided not to do
3839 // it yet as those are used much less than Eq() in practice. A user
3840 // can always write Matcher<T>(Lt(5)) to be explicit about the type,
3841 // for example.
3842 template <typename Lhs, typename Rhs>
3843 inline Matcher<Lhs> TypedEq(const Rhs& rhs) { return Eq(rhs); }
3844

3963 // immediately.

3971 // Creates a matcher that matches an object whose given field matches
3972 // 'matcher'. For example,
3973 // Field(&Foo::number, Ge(5))
3974 // matches a Foo object x iff x.number >= 5.
3975 template <typename Class, typename FieldType, typename FieldMatcher>
3976 inline PolymorphicMatcher<
3977  internal::FieldMatcher<Class, FieldType> > Field(
3978  FieldType Class::*field, const FieldMatcher& matcher) {
3979  return MakePolymorphicMatcher(
3980  internal::FieldMatcher<Class, FieldType>(
3981  field, MatcherCast<const FieldType&>(matcher)));
3982  // The call to MatcherCast() is required for supporting inner
3983  // matchers of compatible types. For example, it allows
3984  // Field(&Foo::bar, m)
3985  // to compile where bar is an int32 and m is a matcher for int64.
3986 }
3987 
3988 // Creates a matcher that matches an object whose given property
3989 // matches 'matcher'. For example,
3990 // Property(&Foo::str, StartsWith("hi"))
3991 // matches a Foo object x iff x.str() starts with "hi".
3992 template <typename Class, typename PropertyType, typename PropertyMatcher>
3993 inline PolymorphicMatcher<internal::PropertyMatcher<
3994  Class, PropertyType, PropertyType (Class::*)() const> >
3995 Property(PropertyType (Class::*property)() const,
3996  const PropertyMatcher& matcher) {
3997  return MakePolymorphicMatcher(
3998  internal::PropertyMatcher<Class, PropertyType,
3999  PropertyType (Class::*)() const>(
4000  property,
4001  MatcherCast<GTEST_REFERENCE_TO_CONST_(PropertyType)>(matcher)));
4002  // The call to MatcherCast() is required for supporting inner
4003  // matchers of compatible types. For example, it allows
4004  // Property(&Foo::bar, m)
4005  // to compile where bar() returns an int32 and m is a matcher for int64.
4006 }

4012  Class, PropertyType, PropertyType (Class::*)() const &> >

4023 // Creates a matcher that matches an object iff the result of applying
4024 // a callable to x matches 'matcher'.
4025 // For example,
4026 // ResultOf(f, StartsWith("hi"))
4027 // matches a Foo object x iff f(x) starts with "hi".
4028 // callable parameter can be a function, function pointer, or a functor.
4029 // Callable has to satisfy the following conditions:
4030 // * It is required to keep no state affecting the results of
4031 // the calls on it and make no assumptions about how many calls
4032 // will be made. Any state it keeps must be protected from the
4033 // concurrent access.
4034 // * If it is a function object, it has to define type result_type.
4035 // We recommend deriving your functor classes from std::unary_function.
4036 template <typename Callable, typename ResultOfMatcher>
4037 internal::ResultOfMatcher<Callable> ResultOf(
4038  Callable callable, const ResultOfMatcher& matcher) {
4039  return internal::ResultOfMatcher<Callable>(
4040  callable,
4041  MatcherCast<typename internal::CallableTraits<Callable>::ResultType>(
4042  matcher));
4043  // The call to MatcherCast() is required for supporting inner
4044  // matchers of compatible types. For example, it allows
4045  // ResultOf(Function, m)
4046  // to compile where Function() returns an int32 and m is a matcher for int64.
4047 }

4240 // Returns a matcher that matches an equal container.

4265 // Returns a matcher that matches a container that, when sorted using
4266 // the < operator, matches container_matcher.
4267 template <typename ContainerMatcher>
4268 inline internal::WhenSortedByMatcher<internal::LessComparator, ContainerMatcher>
4269 WhenSorted(const ContainerMatcher& container_matcher) {
4270  return
4271  internal::WhenSortedByMatcher<internal::LessComparator, ContainerMatcher>(
4272  internal::LessComparator(), container_matcher);
4273 }

4275 // Matches an STL-style container or a native array that contains the
4276 // same number of elements as in rhs, where its i-th element and rhs's
4277 // i-th element (as a pair) satisfy the given pair matcher, for all i.
4278 // TupleMatcher must be able to be safely cast to Matcher<tuple<const
4279 // T1&, const T2&> >, where T1 and T2 are the types of elements in the
4280 // LHS container and the RHS container respectively.
4281 template <typename TupleMatcher, typename Container>
4282 inline internal::PointwiseMatcher<TupleMatcher,
4283  GTEST_REMOVE_CONST_(Container)>
4284 Pointwise(const TupleMatcher& tuple_matcher, const Container& rhs) {
4285  // This following line is for working around a bug in MSVC 8.0,
4286  // which causes Container to be a const type sometimes (e.g. when
4287  // rhs is a const int[])..
4288  typedef GTEST_REMOVE_CONST_(Container) RawContainer;
4289  return internal::PointwiseMatcher<TupleMatcher, RawContainer>(
4290  tuple_matcher, rhs);
4291 }
4292 
4293 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_INITIALIZER_LIST_
4294 
4295 // Supports the Pointwise(m, {a, b, c}) syntax.
4296 template <typename TupleMatcher, typename T>
4297 inline internal::PointwiseMatcher<TupleMatcher, std::vector<T> > Pointwise(
4298  const TupleMatcher& tuple_matcher, std::initializer_list<T> rhs) {
4299  return Pointwise(tuple_matcher, std::vector<T>(rhs));
4300 }
4301 
4302 #endif // GTEST_HAS_STD_INITIALIZER_LIST_
4303 
4304 // UnorderedPointwise(pair_matcher, rhs) matches an STL-style
4305 // container or a native array that contains the same number of
4306 // elements as in rhs, where in some permutation of the container, its
4307 // i-th element and rhs's i-th element (as a pair) satisfy the given
4308 // pair matcher, for all i. Tuple2Matcher must be able to be safely
4309 // cast to Matcher<tuple<const T1&, const T2&> >, where T1 and T2 are
4310 // the types of elements in the LHS container and the RHS container
4311 // respectively.
4312 //
4313 // This is like Pointwise(pair_matcher, rhs), except that the element
4314 // order doesn't matter.
4315 template <typename Tuple2Matcher, typename RhsContainer>
4316 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<
4317  typename internal::BoundSecondMatcher<
4318  Tuple2Matcher, typename internal::StlContainerView<GTEST_REMOVE_CONST_(
4319  RhsContainer)>::type::value_type> >
4320 UnorderedPointwise(const Tuple2Matcher& tuple2_matcher,
4321  const RhsContainer& rhs_container) {
4322  // This following line is for working around a bug in MSVC 8.0,
4323  // which causes RhsContainer to be a const type sometimes (e.g. when
4324  // rhs_container is a const int[]).
4325  typedef GTEST_REMOVE_CONST_(RhsContainer) RawRhsContainer;
4326 
4327  // RhsView allows the same code to handle RhsContainer being a
4328  // STL-style container and it being a native C-style array.
4329  typedef typename internal::StlContainerView<RawRhsContainer> RhsView;
4330  typedef typename RhsView::type RhsStlContainer;
4331  typedef typename RhsStlContainer::value_type Second;
4332  const RhsStlContainer& rhs_stl_container =
4333  RhsView::ConstReference(rhs_container);
4334 
4335  // Create a matcher for each element in rhs_container.
4336  ::std::vector<internal::BoundSecondMatcher<Tuple2Matcher, Second> > matchers;
4337  for (typename RhsStlContainer::const_iterator it = rhs_stl_container.begin();
4338  it != rhs_stl_container.end(); ++it) {
4339  matchers.push_back(
4340  internal::MatcherBindSecond(tuple2_matcher, *it));
4341  }
4342 
4343  // Delegate the work to UnorderedElementsAreArray().
4344  return UnorderedElementsAreArray(matchers);
4345 }
4346 
4347 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_INITIALIZER_LIST_
4348 
4349 // Supports the UnorderedPointwise(m, {a, b, c}) syntax.
4350 template <typename Tuple2Matcher, typename T>
4351 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<
4352  typename internal::BoundSecondMatcher<Tuple2Matcher, T> >
4353 UnorderedPointwise(const Tuple2Matcher& tuple2_matcher,
4354  std::initializer_list<T> rhs) {
4355  return UnorderedPointwise(tuple2_matcher, std::vector<T>(rhs));
4356 }
4357 
4358 #endif // GTEST_HAS_STD_INITIALIZER_LIST_

4360 // Matches an STL-style container or a native array that contains at
4361 // least one element matching the given value or matcher.
4362 //
4363 // Examples:
4364 // ::std::set<int> page_ids;
4365 // page_ids.insert(3);
4366 // page_ids.insert(1);
4367 // EXPECT_THAT(page_ids, Contains(1));
4368 // EXPECT_THAT(page_ids, Contains(Gt(2)));
4369 // EXPECT_THAT(page_ids, Not(Contains(4)));
4370 //
4371 // ::std::map<int, size_t> page_lengths;
4372 // page_lengths[1] = 100;
4373 // EXPECT_THAT(page_lengths,
4374 // Contains(::std::pair<const int, size_t>(1, 100)));
4375 //
4376 // const char* user_ids[] = { "joe", "mike", "tom" };
4377 // EXPECT_THAT(user_ids, Contains(Eq(::std::string("tom"))));
4378 template <typename M>
4379 inline internal::ContainsMatcher<M> Contains(M matcher) {
4380  return internal::ContainsMatcher<M>(matcher);
4381 }

4383 // IsSupersetOf(iterator_first, iterator_last)
4384 // IsSupersetOf(pointer, count)
4385 // IsSupersetOf(array)
4386 // IsSupersetOf(container)
4387 // IsSupersetOf({e1, e2, ..., en})
4388 //
4389 // IsSupersetOf() verifies that a surjective partial mapping onto a collection
4390 // of matchers exists. In other words, a container matches
4391 // IsSupersetOf({e1, ..., en}) if and only if there is a permutation
4392 // {y1, ..., yn} of some of the container's elements where y1 matches e1,
4393 // ..., and yn matches en. Obviously, the size of the container must be >= n
4394 // in order to have a match. Examples:
4395 //
4396 // - {1, 2, 3} matches IsSupersetOf({Ge(3), Ne(0)}), as 3 matches Ge(3) and
4397 // 1 matches Ne(0).
4398 // - {1, 2} doesn't match IsSupersetOf({Eq(1), Lt(2)}), even though 1 matches
4399 // both Eq(1) and Lt(2). The reason is that different matchers must be used
4400 // for elements in different slots of the container.
4401 // - {1, 1, 2} matches IsSupersetOf({Eq(1), Lt(2)}), as (the first) 1 matches
4402 // Eq(1) and (the second) 1 matches Lt(2).
4403 // - {1, 2, 3} matches IsSupersetOf(Gt(1), Gt(1)), as 2 matches (the first)
4404 // Gt(1) and 3 matches (the second) Gt(1).
4405 //
4406 // The matchers can be specified as an array, a pointer and count, a container,
4407 // an initializer list, or an STL iterator range. In each of these cases, the
4408 // underlying matchers can be either values or matchers.
4409 
4410 template <typename Iter>
4411 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<
4412  typename ::std::iterator_traits<Iter>::value_type>
4413 IsSupersetOf(Iter first, Iter last) {
4414  typedef typename ::std::iterator_traits<Iter>::value_type T;
4415  return internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T>(
4416  internal::UnorderedMatcherRequire::Superset, first, last);
4417 }
4418 
4419 template <typename T>
4420 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T> IsSupersetOf(
4421  const T* pointer, size_t count) {
4422  return IsSupersetOf(pointer, pointer + count);
4423 }
4424 
4425 template <typename T, size_t N>
4426 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T> IsSupersetOf(
4427  const T (&array)[N]) {
4428  return IsSupersetOf(array, N);
4429 }
4430 
4431 template <typename Container>
4432 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<
4433  typename Container::value_type>
4434 IsSupersetOf(const Container& container) {
4435  return IsSupersetOf(container.begin(), container.end());
4436 }
4437 
4438 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_INITIALIZER_LIST_
4439 template <typename T>
4440 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T> IsSupersetOf(
4441  ::std::initializer_list<T> xs) {
4442  return IsSupersetOf(xs.begin(), xs.end());
4443 }
4444 #endif

4446 // IsSubsetOf(iterator_first, iterator_last)
4447 // IsSubsetOf(pointer, count)
4448 // IsSubsetOf(array)
4449 // IsSubsetOf(container)
4450 // IsSubsetOf({e1, e2, ..., en})
4451 //
4452 // IsSubsetOf() verifies that an injective mapping onto a collection of matchers
4453 // exists. In other words, a container matches IsSubsetOf({e1, ..., en}) if and
4454 // only if there is a subset of matchers {m1, ..., mk} which would match the
4455 // container using UnorderedElementsAre. Obviously, the size of the container
4456 // must be <= n in order to have a match. Examples:
4457 //
4458 // - {1} matches IsSubsetOf({Gt(0), Lt(0)}), as 1 matches Gt(0).
4459 // - {1, -1} matches IsSubsetOf({Lt(0), Gt(0)}), as 1 matches Gt(0) and -1
4460 // matches Lt(0).
4461 // - {1, 2} doesn't matches IsSubsetOf({Gt(0), Lt(0)}), even though 1 and 2 both
4462 // match Gt(0). The reason is that different matchers must be used for
4463 // elements in different slots of the container.
4464 //
4465 // The matchers can be specified as an array, a pointer and count, a container,
4466 // an initializer list, or an STL iterator range. In each of these cases, the
4467 // underlying matchers can be either values or matchers.
4468 
4469 template <typename Iter>
4470 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<
4471  typename ::std::iterator_traits<Iter>::value_type>
4472 IsSubsetOf(Iter first, Iter last) {
4473  typedef typename ::std::iterator_traits<Iter>::value_type T;
4474  return internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T>(
4475  internal::UnorderedMatcherRequire::Subset, first, last);
4476 }
4477 
4478 template <typename T>
4479 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T> IsSubsetOf(
4480  const T* pointer, size_t count) {
4481  return IsSubsetOf(pointer, pointer + count);
4482 }
4483 
4484 template <typename T, size_t N>
4485 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T> IsSubsetOf(
4486  const T (&array)[N]) {
4487  return IsSubsetOf(array, N);
4488 }
4489 
4490 template <typename Container>
4491 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<
4492  typename Container::value_type>
4493 IsSubsetOf(const Container& container) {
4494  return IsSubsetOf(container.begin(), container.end());
4495 }
4496 
4497 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_INITIALIZER_LIST_
4498 template <typename T>
4499 inline internal::UnorderedElementsAreArrayMatcher<T> IsSubsetOf(
4500  ::std::initializer_list<T> xs) {
4501  return IsSubsetOf(xs.begin(), xs.end());
4502 }

4505 // Matches an STL-style container or a native array that contains only
4506 // elements matching the given value or matcher.
4507 //
4508 // Each(m) is semantically equivalent to Not(Contains(Not(m))). Only
4509 // the messages are different.
4510 //
4511 // Examples:
4512 // ::std::set<int> page_ids;
4513 // // Each(m) matches an empty container, regardless of what m is.
4514 // EXPECT_THAT(page_ids, Each(Eq(1)));
4515 // EXPECT_THAT(page_ids, Each(Eq(77)));
4516 //
4517 // page_ids.insert(3);
4518 // EXPECT_THAT(page_ids, Each(Gt(0)));
4519 // EXPECT_THAT(page_ids, Not(Each(Gt(4))));
4520 // page_ids.insert(1);
4521 // EXPECT_THAT(page_ids, Not(Each(Lt(2))));
4522 //
4523 // ::std::map<int, size_t> page_lengths;
4524 // page_lengths[1] = 100;
4525 // page_lengths[2] = 200;
4526 // page_lengths[3] = 300;
4527 // EXPECT_THAT(page_lengths, Not(Each(Pair(1, 100))));
4528 // EXPECT_THAT(page_lengths, Each(Key(Le(3))));
4529 //
4530 // const char* user_ids[] = { "joe", "mike", "tom" };
4531 // EXPECT_THAT(user_ids, Not(Each(Eq(::std::string("tom")))));
4532 template <typename M>
4533 inline internal::EachMatcher<M> Each(M matcher) {
4534  return internal::EachMatcher<M>(matcher);
4535 }
4536 
4537 // Key(inner_matcher) matches an std::pair whose 'first' field matches
4538 // inner_matcher. For example, Contains(Key(Ge(5))) can be used to match an
4539 // std::map that contains at least one element whose key is >= 5.
4540 template <typename M>
4541 inline internal::KeyMatcher<M> Key(M inner_matcher) {
4542  return internal::KeyMatcher<M>(inner_matcher);
4543 }
4544 
4545 // Pair(first_matcher, second_matcher) matches a std::pair whose 'first' field
4546 // matches first_matcher and whose 'second' field matches second_matcher. For
4547 // example, EXPECT_THAT(map_type, ElementsAre(Pair(Ge(5), "foo"))) can be used
4548 // to match a std::map<int, string> that contains exactly one element whose key
4549 // is >= 5 and whose value equals "foo".
4550 template <typename FirstMatcher, typename SecondMatcher>
4551 inline internal::PairMatcher<FirstMatcher, SecondMatcher>
4552 Pair(FirstMatcher first_matcher, SecondMatcher second_matcher) {
4553  return internal::PairMatcher<FirstMatcher, SecondMatcher>(
4554  first_matcher, second_matcher);
4555 }

4557 // Returns a predicate that is satisfied by anything that matches the
4558 // given matcher.
4559 template <typename M>
4560 inline internal::MatcherAsPredicate<M> Matches(M matcher) {
4561  return internal::MatcherAsPredicate<M>(matcher);
4562 }

4614 // These macros allow using matchers to check values in Google Test
4615 // tests. ASSERT_THAT(value, matcher) and EXPECT_THAT(value, matcher)
4616 // succeed iff the value matches the matcher. If the assertion fails,
4617 // the value and the description of the matcher will be printed.

4621  ::testing::internal::MakePredicateFormatterFromMatcher(matcher), value)
